”A New Way to See” is really a photo workshop where young people
take cameras to shoot their homes and neighborhoods as they see them.
The purpose is the title as the kids begin to find another way of
communicating ... their pictures telling more than they can say.
The Housing Hangup, Integration vs. Seperatism, The Performing
Arts, a talent show tied into three such shows already underway in local
schools and parks ... these are only a few of the features of ”ItTs Our
Bag.” The show hosted by .Sylvia Rolle and co-hosted on a rotating
'basis by DJTs from the rock-and-soul radio station WMBM extends its
audience each night when the audio track is replayed on WMBM, a station
that hits the black youth where they live.
CONTACT: Bea Baxter, Producer, ”ItTs Our Bag”
KCET, Los Angeles is enthusiastic about its "Black Perspective”
a series that for the first time gives the Southern California black
press an outlet. Frankly patterned in meet-the-press format, the series
takes on a variety of guests and issues. The difference: the questions
are posed by black reporters who query out of gut level experience.
CONTACT: Charles Allen, Program Director
KTCA-TV, the Twin City Area Educational Television Station is tackling
social and economic problems confronting the black population with
"Black Voices.*’ The program also showcases black art, theater and
history. The idea of the program is stated at the top of each show,
"Black Voices is for black people, but anyone can watch, can listen,
can think.”
The Twin Cities station also program a fiteen minute production
called "The Runner” produced by and for the approximately 20,000
Chippewa and Sioux Indians in the area. The programs are straight¬
forward news presentations, giving information concerning affairs at
the reservation, updating information from all Federal Agencies which
deal with Indians and Indian community problems. Special note: members
of the Twin City Indian community are in. the process of themselves
raising money in order to insure continuation of the series.
CONTACT: Joseph T. McDermott, Director,of Project Development
for the Twin City Area Educational Television Station.
WMSB, East Lansing connected with a group of ADC mothers on a
project called ’’Welfare Rights Mothers Visit Kathe Kollowitz.” The
women, either thought of negatively (or not at all) by the community
were invited to visit a travelling exhibit of prints by Kathe Kollowitz.
Then they sat down and talked about the experience ... about the prints,
about art, about themselves in relation to art. They did not discuss
being on welfare. They talked, out of their own valid intelligence,
about the art that touched them as human beings.
The Community was astounded. Who ever heard of women on relief
talking about art? East Lansing did, and the town learned something.
